results.title: The Who: who's better, who's best
results.brief_description: The Who! What’s in a name you say? everything, especially when you talk about the world’s greatest rock ‘n’ roll band, a name bestowed upon this group of 4 English musicians in the mid ‘70’s. The Who, formed in 1964 and consisting of Keith Moon on drums, John Entwhistle on bass guitar and vocals, Pete Townshend - lead guitar, vocals and major lyricist for the group and Roger Daltry - main vocals. All of the tracks included on the tape come from the album “Who’s Better, Who’s Best” (made in 1980), although this video does take you on a journey from 1966 through to 1978. Moon died tragically in August of that year. Keith Moon’s distinct style of drumming is evident in all the film clips except for “You Better, You Bet” with Kenny Jones on drums. The song “Pinball Wizard” from the Rock Opera “Tommy” - considered by many as the definitive rock album, is only one of the many hits contained on the tape. As is “Won’t Get Fooled Again”, filmed at the Shepparton Studios in July 1978 and became the group’s signature song. Song on the tape include: “My Generation”; “I can’t explain”; “Substitute”; “The kids are alright”; “I’m a boy”; “Happy Jack”; “Pictures of Lily”; “You better, you bet”; “I can see for miles”; “Magic bus”; “Pinball wizard”; “I’m free”; “See me, feel me”; “Join together”; “Who are you” and “Won’t get fooled again”.

results.title: The White walking stick
results.brief_description: To be blind is not to be cut off from everything in life, there are still shapes, smells, and sounds to be understood and enjoyed. The Blind Institute in Auckland undertakes to teach the blind and partially blind to becomes self sufficient and happily employed. Blind persons are shown in various industries. A housewife is shown cooking with the aid of Braille thermometer and cookery book. In the school for blind children every child is given individual tuition and taught to co-ordinate fingertips and brain. It is in music that blind people excel.

results.title: The White ship
results.creator_credit: Hector Lemieux, Rex Tasker and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Shows one of the Portuguese schooners that still fish the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. Follows the ship and its crew from the time the townsfolk turn out for the blessing, until the ship returns with the season’s catch, and leaving one crewman in a Newfoundland grave.

results.title: The White House
results.creator_credit: John B. Bredar, National Geographic Society and National Geographic Television
results.brief_description: In 1789 an idea forged by America’s first President, George Washington, received Congress approval. Washington’s aim was to build a new capital city and a President’s House away from New York on the river Potomac. Construction began in 1792 with the foundations being dug by slaves and half the workforce made up of immigrants. Built of iron and stone this magnificent building became a symbol of the American people and a symbol of power to the rest of the world. Unfortunately, George Washington died before the building was completed. This documentary takes you into the world of the White House and its day-to-day running, including the huge entourage of staff who serve the House - plumbers, electricians, maids and butlers, chefs and kitchen hands, event co-ordinators and managers. You will see a State Dinner being organised and prepared for 150 guests with the Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, as the distinguished State visitor, as well as rare shots of the living quarters where Presidents and their families have resided for over 200 years. Also includes historical footage, photographic stills and anecdotal stories from past Presidents, their families and employees at the White House. Narrated by Morgan Freeman. Contains some black and white footage.

results.title: The White frontier
results.brief_description: An account of the work of the British North Greenland Expedition, 1952, which set out to probe the secrets of the Greenland ice-cap. Shows the arrival of the Norwegian sealing vessel at the Expedition’s southern base at Britannia, and the setting out of the small group of explorers to establish observations posts 250 miles from the main camp.

results.title: The White cloud: the truck of Joe Madrid
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Clapp, Anthony Loeb and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: The first person narration in coloquial American spoken by Mexican-American truck driver, Joe Madrid, adds credibility and charm to this unpretentious work. His truck ferries perishable goods worth thousands of dollars across the continent. As he drives he talks about his work, truck and family.

results.title: The Whispering giant
results.brief_description: The story of the Bristol Britannia, Britain’s great hundred-seater, turbo-prop airliner, the first to operate a scheduled non-stop service across the Atlantic between London and New York. Ten years of specialised design and research went into the Britannia and the development of the aircraft from its inception in the planning offices of the Bristol Aeroplane Company. Shows the elaborate testing stages, test flights and the process of production; the proving flights and finally the actual operation of the Britannia by airlines in Britain, Canada, the USA and Mexico.

results.title: The What did you think of the movie movie
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Kagan and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This delightful satire of movie criticism covers the complete range of responses to the question in its title. In the most hilarious scenes, some of the “critics” warm up to their task and get carried away by their reactions to life on the silver screen.

results.title: The Whales are waiting
results.creator_credit: Andy Thomson, Strowan Robertson, Tony Ianzelo, Bill Brind and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Discusses the organisation called Project Jonah, which is committed to bringing about a moratorium on the killing of whales. Executive producer, Colin Law; editor, Marion Meadows.
